summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding the case against Ghislaine Maxwell. It proposes a briefing schedule for the detention memorandum and requests an exclusion of time under the Speedy Trial Act, following Maxwell's arrest.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge in the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell; the letter is addressed to her and requests scheduling and procedural rulings.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in the criminal case (20 Cr. 330); the document concerns scheduling for her initial proceeding, arraignment, and bail hearing following her arrest.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: Signatory of the letter on behalf of the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, submitting the Government's proposals to the court.

connections.description: Strauss, as Acting U.S. Attorney, is representing the Government prosecuting Maxwell, as indicated by the case caption and the letter's content.
Judge Nathan is the presiding judicial officer over the criminal case against defendant Maxwell.

events.title: Arrest of Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell was arrested, as referenced in the context of the Government's request to exclude time under the Speedy Trial Act from this date.

events.title: Proposed Remote Initial Proceeding
events.description: The parties (Government and defense) are available to proceed remotely for an initial court proceeding, which would include arraignment and a bail hearing.

events.title: Defense Response Due
events.description: Proposed deadline for the defense to file its response to the Government's Memorandum in Support of Detention.

events.title: Government Reply Due
events.description: Proposed deadline for the Government to file its reply to the defense's response regarding detention.

locations: Silvio J. Mollo Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell was arrested on July 2, 2020, and the Government is seeking to schedule her initial court appearance.
The parties proposed a remote proceeding for July 14, 2020, and a briefing schedule for detention arguments.
The Government requested an exclusion of time under the Speedy Trial Act from the date of arrest to facilitate discovery and preparation.
This document is an early procedural filing in the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell (20 Cr. 330).
